posts.name: KANDREGULA LAKSHMI VENKATA KARTHIKEY
posts.cooked:
ls -lh
find . -type f -size +5513c -newermt “1994-09-23 00:00:00” -printf “%s %p\n”
find . -type f -size +5513c -newermt “1994-09-23 00:00:00” -printf “%s\n” | awk ‘{ total += $1 } END { print total }’
After executing these I am getting 355767 but it is showing that this is incorrect. My Quiz id is 40babd60699a472aa649346e95ca8927.

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Hi Kandregula,

I have checked your specific GA. I am able to get the correct answer (not using your particular script). Please check the results carefully of what your script produces and verify that it is working as intended.

Kind regards

posts.name: KANDREGULA LAKSHMI VENKATA KARTHIKEY
posts.cooked:
sir I tried with code
find . -type f -size +5513c -newermt “1994-09-23 00:00:00” -exec ls -lh {} +
find . -type f -size +5513c -newermt “1994-09-23 00:00:00” -exec du -b {} + | awk ‘{sum += $1} END {print sum}’
still getting 355767. is there anything wrong with the code?

posts.name: Carlton D'Silva
posts.cooked:
Try cross checking with google sheets. See if by using filters you can arrive at the same list. Use ls -l. Then copy into google sheets. Convert text to columns. Use filters. And then check. If the lists are different try to see why they are different and see if you can spot the difference between the list your script produces vs what it should be.

Regards

posts.name: KANDREGULA LAKSHMI VENKATA KARTHIKEY
posts.cooked: Sir i sorted the file in excel and moved all the files with the given criterion to another folder and checked the size its coming out 350253 still it is wrong

posts.name: Anand S
posts.cooked:
@23f1001992 – could you please subtract 1 day (i.e. 1994-09-22 instead of 1994-09-23) and try? I think it’ll work.

Or, put another way, include the file JUST before the cutoff time.

There’s a subtle time zone bug in JSZip - so times mentioned in IST are actually in UTC.

This is fixed for all future test-takers.

link_counts.title: Last Modified time for zip entries is UTC time · Issue #369 · Stuk/jszip · GitHub

posts.name: Vikash Kumar Jha
posts.cooked:
When extracting files from a ZIP archive using Windows’ built-in “Extract All” feature, you may notice that all extracted files have the same modification date. This is default behavior in Windows and can cause issues if you need accurate file dates.

To preserve the original file modification dates:

  1. Use the unzip command instead of Windows’ extraction tool.
  2. In Visual Studio Code, open a terminal as Git Bash, which provides access to the unzip command.
  3. Run the unzip command to extract the files which will maintain their original timestamps.

Also i had to add 1 day to get the correct answer.
